positive.review: Co-Op Hades that replaces story for more charachters and diverging gameplay. Well worth the purchase if you like that game style.

Good game. I have about 925 hours at the time of writing this review. Slow paced combat. Three chapters, all 18 minutes long. A boss fight at the end of each chapter. you get stronger with hero talents and magical objects that you collect along the way. 4 man CO-OP is available. 
There's a lot of thought and polish to the gameplay and combat mechanics. All heroes are well balanced. (not all are equal, of course. some are stronger than others)

The biggest con for me is how stale the game can feel after you've finished the highest difficulty. The developers are extremely slow to bring changes and new patches to the game. Quite a lot of very basic features are missing like color blindness accessibility. The lobby is very buggy. The netcode is not the best. Random disconnects and straight up game crashes can happen from time to time.

This is one of the more challenging rouge likes out there. Even at the easiest difficulty, it took me 5-6 tries before I beat the game on the first character. If you're someone who thrives on stagger mechanics and feel the thrill when playing games where every hit feels like life and death then this game will be for you. If you're looking for something more casual and stress-free to play, then there are other games out there.

This game is well-polished and has a great aesthetic. Every character feels unique and their abilities play to their lore. There are some characters like Pied Piper who feel terrible to play in the early levels but every character is capable of becoming OP if you build them right and min/max. Every run has a time limit on how long you can spend running around the map and acquiring loot and strength which will make or break the game. As you increase in difficulty, the min/maxing becomes more important and you'll feel more pigeon-held into playing certain builds in order to win the round. 

Overall, I enjoyed the time that I spent playing Ravenswatch and appreciate the love that was put into this game. The devs seem to care about the community and occasionally release free DLC to improve the game.
Aside from occasional network issue, the game is polished and fun if you are playing solo or multiplayer!

A lot of really cool ideas in the game, the collection of well known characters from all around put into one setting was the main draw for me. For the most part, they have interesting mechanics and playstyles. The voice acting, soundtrack, artwork are all great. I just find the game to be a bit dull to play. All from the perspective of a solo player, but eh. Recommend for the amount of love that's clearly been put into the game.

Worth a try, it might jive better with other action roguelike enjoyers.
[spoiler] Wukong is my easily my favorite, really sick to see him in the game [/spoiler]

Great game. I would love to see it being developed further. Especially adding some variety to the maps - maybe final bosses variations and some shape changes? It gets a bit repetitive in this departments, but quality of character design compensate it for now. 

I love how runs don't make your chars stronger. It's unlocking you some build options, but not always stroner ones really. Just nicely balanced for different playstyles and RNG. But you feel, that you are actually getting stronger, cause you gain knowledge about map, enemies and how your character really works. And the difference is HUGE! With skilled party of 3 people we are melting the bosses now, where we struggled to survive on the beggining. 

Extremly fun and worth the money! I wish skins would be more than just recolors (in most DLCs), cause I would definitely buy some to leave devs more money.

The game is amazing and great fun to play with friends. The amount of work and detailing put into the game plus a free DLC is just mindblowing. The game is quick and you love each build every time. It's unique and a must play. 10/10

I highly recommend. The heros are done with such panache and intelligence that it made me feel like I was playing Dawngate again, which is a compliment not to be thrown out lightly. My one critique is that the three worlds begin to feel very samey after a few dozen runs. It really would've benefited the game's endurance to have more of a variety on that end.

Excellent graphics, character mechanics and challenge progression. This game has a lot of potential.

Got 14 hours out of this game and it was fun, but I can't imagine trying to take a second character up to high difficulty. Each character takes literal hours of grinding to unlock their full kit. Builds are entirely centered around hero-specific skills; items also exist but they aren't transformative to your playstyle and don't combo the way skills do. This means that build diversity is super dependent on grinding up each individual character from scratch.
Great and very addictive game! Fun to play over and over again while switching between characters. Big W

Fun, pretty straight forward roguelike; easy to learn, difficult to master, lots of player choice, lots of power-ups.

Pros:
Great difficulty options (XP reduction on top of increasing dmg/hp)
Plenty of build options for all of the characters. My group has argued which 'build' is the best for each, only for it to be beaten by a random amalgam of talents and items that just work flawlessly together. But "Peak" exists.
You WILL find the character that you vibe with, and once they are mastered, you'll realize other character's potentials. (Beowolf is my champion of choice, but now I play any character so Random is fine)
Solid 100+ hours of gameplay for $25 is worth it. I'm not at 100 hours (yet), but its only a matter of time.

Cons:
The map/regions get a little repetitive, but it just means you know your way around which optimize the runs.
Some bosses make it nearly impossible to pick up a downed ally. Each boss has 8+ attack options, but picks 3 per encounter.
Can be REALLY frustrating at time, but it is 100% the player's fault for standing in the big red circle.
This game is quite a bit of fun, and if you have any sort of completionist tendencies it has great replay value.  I love the music/sound engineering, and this is a TON of fun to play with friends.

Fantastic Roguelike game. Loads of fun alone and with friends. The hero design is unlike anything i've seen, every single playable character is fun to play and has multiple fun ways to build them. Nice enough to play 50+ hours in co-op where this game really shines playing with friends (good with 2 people, better with 3 or 4). Solo gameplay feels more suited for training, discovering and farming levels on the characters (with no time limit, 1x fewer cycle) than a true well balanced solo gameplay experience.

Had a good time for my buck, yet a few things to improve for a more enjoyable replay loop :

1st on the characters
* Some characters are way easier and robust than others, so you end up having "must have" characters in the group for hard runs (ex: Melusine is busted on group healing/shield ; Beowulf gathers super solid crit chance conditions + block&shield skills for tank role). Would be nice if there were more characters with stable builds for tanking/healing that do not fall to rng of talent picks.
* Some characters really lack valuable group assets : they bring either so little or solo buff/shield/heals or their trigger conditions induce horrible up time. You end up playing alongside each others instead of co-op with good synergies.
* Balance between the random pick mechanic for talents and each character talents game design can make some character runs really unreliable and frustrating in harder difficulties either because there is a must have talent to make the character build work (that you might never get, even with many stars of fate) or because the overall number of viable talents is too low so you will never get seven or even 6 good/synergy talents and items.
Note : when you crush down the numbers, some characters have less than 50% chance to get 7 good talents even if you use one star of fate EVERY talent pick (assuming you picked stars of fate during the run instead of buffs to be able to reroll that much...). Its worse than betting the fun of your run on a coin flip!

2nd on the map
* Boss diversity starts lacking after 50+ hours of playtime, would be nice to add more lvl options. The current loop is still a solid one, other branches to reach final boss would be a nice addition to the game.

3rd random disconnects:
* no matter the reason, if you get disconnected, game is over... was it after 5min on 1st level, or after 50min of playtime just before last boss ? Only difference will be the level of frustration it brings :p Please add some way to reconnect to the party...

Great game with lots of depth in decision making and mastery of the game systems. There's an extremely satisfying "flow of play" difficulty curve in this game where navigating the map efficiently can turn a good run into an excellent one. 

The timer based gameplay may not be for everyone, but it keeps the pacing of the game as fast as you can handle, and finding that balance between being careful and staying on the move is where the entire experience lives. The higher difficulty levels stress this balance even further, putting more and more pressure on your ability to stay ahead without making mistakes.

There's a great amount of variety in the core cast of heroes, genuinely there's something for everyone here. The stages, bosses, events, enemies, and just about everything else (barring some randomization of positions on the map and some RNG on availability) remain basically static run to run, so you'll really be looking to change up your hero to add some variety to gameplay. 

While there is some meta progression, it's minimal. Some characters do unlock what you could argue are their "better" abilities by way of completing runs with them, but there isn't anything intrinsic to the meta progression that makes the game "easier" like it sometimes does in roguelites. At best you could make the argument that your favorite hero gets their superior ultimate after a couple runs, but you get access to a full kit from the go

The co-op is brilliant, and I should caution any potential buyer that I've essentially *never* played this game by myself. I don't know if you would truly get the whole experience alone - even the idle banter between the heroes is reliant on there being another hero present. To me, all of the experiences worth having in this game have been moments between friends.

It's a solid game, extremely sharply made, but at the end of the day it's ground that's been tread before and truly I feel the co-op is the standout feature here. Absolutely buy it if you have someone to play with.
Way more fun with friends. Still fun by yourself. If you like great roguelikes/roguelites, this is one.

I bought this game because a friend insisted. I played with him and had a blast, decide to play it solo, and i was surprised at how much fun it was. Ravenswatch is an excellent coop, rogue action RPG. It excels above the rest as it offers an assortment of distinctive characters. Each plays differently from the others with multiple skills to construct varied builds. While they are familiar characters, they each have a unique presentation and creatively fit into the world.

The game features more of an open map, newly laid out each run, rather that a series of random rooms like in Hades or Sworn. The map has treasure, power ups, side quests and bosses scattered throughout with a time limit on what you can achieve before the world boss appears. This makes for a highly replayable game as you do not have enough time to hit everything.

The difficulty is quite challenging and can be a bit unpredictable as some runs go smoothly while others are toilsome. There are layers of difficulty to play through as well, which I’ve barely scratched the surface of and epilogue content which is yet foreign to me. 

The graphics, style and performance are all top notch. The content and care added since early access is commendable and the developers continue to update. It is the definition of labor of love and my nominee for the 2025 award.

Risk of Rain 2 stays engaging because you don't know what each stage is going to be until you're in it. You don't know which bosses you're going to fight in a given run. 

Unfortunately Ravenswatch is extremely predictable and once you figure out which things are or aren't worth doing, the game becomes pretty monotonous.
The game is good but it has two very important and simple shortcomings: the ability to reconnect to a session if the game crashes or disconnects, and the ability to pause the game.

A challenging game with buttery smooth gameplay and a really cool art style/aesthetic. Each run takes about an hour, separated into three chapters (in a solo run you have the option of saving and quitting in between chapters), and each chapter puts you on an 18-minute timer during which you have to explore the map, clearing points of interest and getting as strong as you can before fighting the chapter boss to progress. 

The time pressure adds a lot to the difficulty of the game, especially when you're just learning. There is a modifier you can activate to turn the timer off, at the cost of earning achievements and character outfits if you just want to practice. The solo balancing is also really good. Because of the enemy scaling, it can actually be easier than multiplayer.

Great coop game ! However to me, the fact that you need so much xp to level up characters, and that you need to level up the same character several times to unlock parts of different builds, makes the replayability not so great in my opinion.

In most roguelites, you have some kind of meta-currency, that allows you to unlock upgrades for whatever you want, but that is not the case in Ravenswatch. You only earn xp for the character that you take on a run, earning more the further you go. This means that you are rewarded for playing longer runs, but it also means that you will be forced to play the same basic builds with each character for quite a while. I wish that you could instead just allocate xp points to the desired character, so that you can try out other characters, then go back to the one you like to try out a new build.

But yeah, regardless, this is an easy thumbs up for me !
Once you get the hang of each character, it's a lot of fun to explore what they're capable of! Would wait for 50% off since not all characters may be your style which may change how you feel.
I loved Hades & Hades II, but this is Hades on steroids with much more good variation (rather than just RNG) and much more replayability.

After playing this game from 1.0 onward, every patch has made the game harder and less fun in co-op groups. I play in groups of 2 to 4 people total and we went from beating or almost beating the game on the 3rd/4th difficulty each run (and having a BLAST), to now struggling with RNG drops to get past the 2nd difficulty.  We full clear each map usually as well.

After each big update, things have gotten significantly tougher. The addition of new events has been interesting, but each event also dilutes the item/reward pool, making character power progression feel weaker. This, combined with what seems like an overall increase in difficulty, has made it a lot harder for us to enjoy the game the way we used to. Now, we’re struggling a lot more, and honestly, it’s starting to drive all of my friends away.

One of the most frustrating parts is spending nearly an hour on a run, only to reach a boss we used to do well on and get completely wiped. Losing is part of the game, but when we used to have a good shot at winning and now feel like we're barely scraping by, it just doesn’t feel fun anymore. It’s disheartening to put in all that time and effort, only to hit a wall that didn’t used to be there.

I totally understand that updates are meant to keep the game fresh, and I respect the devs for working hard to improve Ravenswatch. But making an already-challenging base difficulty even harder feels like it might be pushing away more casual players like us. I’m worried that if this continues, we’ll have to stop playing altogether - not because we don’t love the game, but because it just isn’t as fun anymore. 

I won't be playing any more and I certainly cannot recommend this game in its current state and trajectory. The game has lost its appeal and is no longer fun to play.

Pros:
-Interesting, playable characters with unique skills and specialties that unlock as you progress.
-Each character has their own lore and story.
-MOBA-style gameplay mechanics combined with action-roguelike elements.

Cons:
-As a solo player, the game is difficult and frustrating, even when grinding to level up your character.
-The difficulty is comparable to Dark Souls, where even small mistakes can lead to instant death, and enemies deal as much damage as you do.
-No difficulty options unless you beat the game, which makes it even harder.

Conclusion:
This game is unique with interesting characters, but it needs more polish. As you grind, there should be bonus stats added to make progress smoother/easier so you’re not struggling as much the next time you play. Sadly, I haven’t tried multiplayer yet, but I’ve heard it's even more difficult than solo play. Due to the high difficulty, reminiscent of Dark Souls, I’ve lost interest in this game, especially since other similar games offer more options and rewards. If the developers improve the game, I’d gladly give it another chance and offer a positive review.

One of those ones where you wish it wasn't just a Yes or No option if you recommend.

This game clearly has a lot of love in it, but it feels undercooked. There's really not that much variety of any kind in it; enemies, bosses, builds, etc. There's enough to make it worth a purchase on sale, but it feels like there's entire features missing and even a level or two.

Also, the most egregious thing and what made my give it a "no" review, is that there is no way to re-join a game if you crash or disconnect (happened to me 2x in 8 hours). The hour you just spent just evaporates, whilst the other players continue on. I can see people complaining about this 10 months ago and the fact it hasn't been addressed makes me think it's unlikely the game has particularly attentive devs - take from that what you will.

If you can get this for around $10 then you'll get your money's worth, but I wouldn't expect this figure to go up much unless the devs pull their finger out and add more content.

The game looks great and clearly has potential, but the pacing kills it for me. Progression feels almost nonexistent. I have replayed the first level five or six times and it is just tedious. There is no real sense of growth, power, or clear goals. Instead of feeling like I am getting stronger, every run feels the same which makes it repetitive very quickly.

Other players have pointed out the same issues: limited map variety, not enough enemy types, and a grindy loop that does not reward your time

The foundation is there, but it needs faster progression, more variety, and a better sense of leveling up before it can become something special. Right now it is too boring and too slow, and I am honestly considering a refund.

After playing this game from 1.0 onward, every patch has made the game harder and less fun in co-op groups. I play in groups of 2 to 4 people total and we went from beating or almost beating the game on the 3rd/4th difficulty each run (and having a BLAST), to now struggling with RNG drops to get past the 2nd difficulty.  We full clear each map usually as well.

After each big update, things have gotten significantly tougher. The addition of new events has been interesting, but each event also dilutes the item/reward pool, making character power progression feel weaker. This, combined with what seems like an overall increase in difficulty, has made it a lot harder for us to enjoy the game the way we used to. Now, we’re struggling a lot more, and honestly, it’s starting to drive all of my friends away.

One of the most frustrating parts is spending nearly an hour on a run, only to reach a boss we used to do well on and get completely wiped. Losing is part of the game, but when we used to have a good shot at winning and now feel like we're barely scraping by, it just doesn’t feel fun anymore. It’s disheartening to put in all that time and effort, only to hit a wall that didn’t used to be there.

I totally understand that updates are meant to keep the game fresh, and I respect the devs for working hard to improve Ravenswatch. But making an already-challenging base difficulty even harder feels like it might be pushing away more casual players like us. I’m worried that if this continues, we’ll have to stop playing altogether - not because we don’t love the game, but because it just isn’t as fun anymore. 

I won't be playing any more and I certainly cannot recommend this game in its current state and trajectory. The game has lost its appeal and is no longer fun to play.

It just feels too small and repetitive, runs are too much alike.
The combat feels great though.

Although it's got some good things going for it, the variety of the roguelike aspects are pretty lacking. There's only a few maps, and those maps are super frustrating to traverse because there are random walls everywhere. See a treasure chest nearby on the mini-map? Have fun walking around a giant circle to find the small stairway that leads to it.

The damage scaling is pretty unbalanced, some guys will 1-shot you if you don't dodge their charge attacks, while others barely scratch you.

The upgrades are pretty generic "this does 5% more damage" and the UI to navigate everything leaves a lot to be desired. It took me a while to figure out I had to open the mini-map in order to hover over my all my skills/upgrades to see what's going on. Why can't I see the same details when I hit escape? or hold alt? Not sure.

Maybe pick it up if it's on a really good sale.

It's a good idea in concept, but there's just something a little wrong in the execution. Not enough maps, yeah, the mobs are all same-y, sure, but the main issue to me is that the runs just overstay their welcome. Three maps at a minimum of 15 minutes each means you'll be spending at least 55 minutes on a run if you're killing the bosses in five each. That's quite the commitment for a roguelike, and you can only save+quit at the end of each map, meaning every 20~ish minutes.

It would be a lot better if it was one map with options on game time and sizes: small, medium, and large maps for 15, 30, and 45 minutes respectively. If they add a more bite-sized gamemode I'll likely change my review to positive.

On paper, this should be a game I love: Great theme, level-based co-op game, progression, etc...
In practice, it just annoys me. Everything is based on how quickly you can kill anything, a lot of bosses have no reward if you don't kill them in time, EVERYTHING is timed.
Yes, there is a mode with no timer, but you're locked out of any sort of metaprogression if you enable it.

The combat is also pretty lackluster, from my experience, it's mostly waiting for cooldowns and dodging enemies. If you're playing any sort of melee character it's a death-sentence going in without an escape button on.

So in essence if you hate being rushed, dislike rewards being denied to you from bosses despite beating them and don't want to feel annoyed by everything, this is not the game for you.
